We cannot here pass over the advice of
bruyerinus. respecting the preparing of cab
bage for the table.


81 must" says he. "expose an error
which is no less common than pernicious, in
preparing cabbage. Most people, in conse-
quence of the ignorance of their cooks, eat
it after it has been long boiled, a circum-
stance which does not little diminish both
its grateful taste and salutary qualities But
those who have more polite and elegant
turn. order their cabbage to be slightly boil
ed, put into dishes and seasoned with salt
and oil; by which method they assume a
beautiful green color, become grateful to
the taste, and proper for keeping the bo-
dy soluble. This circumstance ought not to
be forgotten by those who are lovers of cab
bage.


"The ancients Boiled their cabbage with
nitre, which rendered it at once more CRATE.
full to the palate and more agreeable to the
eye"


Phillips History Of Vegetables.
COOKING CABBAGE.

To the Editor Of the ItiminStonian.


In your last Number, an additional toz2
and scurrious publication has appeared "a
gainst me from the famous would-oe rus
tees Of St. Peters Church, backed by the
certificate of Patrick Higgins, and the alter
picc, of the notorious Quack Doctor, OF Oh
hossum memory. That shameful production,
fraught with the most glaring falsehoods, is
degrading, and unworthy the character OF
apv Trustees, and which, as member, !
much regret.


/ have turned those "Trustees" over to
,he legal authority WHO have no doubt will
dulv appre ciate their wants, and do them
THAI in ,tict their infamous deeds deserve.
Nj statement, by way Of reply, in your
forncr paper, is substantially correct; and
have heen, and am ready and willingto settle
on lust aud equitable term, with the church,
with any men selected who are not devoid OF
/ principle, but ] ntver can condescend to
men s. destitute Of every principle that cha
ractcrizes the individuals who have so wan
tony ;ssaied my character


! With respect to the certificate OF Patrick,
| il is bundle of absurdities worthy the au-
thor He saws he has known me for TWEEN
| ty-fiye Years lit is true, and the only truth
he has asserted y: he has known me, and
have we'll known him to my sorrow. He can
advert to the time and we'll remember, who
! first started him in Thoroughfare Neck, and
who it was that was the loser thereby byhis ,r-
yegulQr spQys, and who afterwards helped
\ him back to Wilmington, and aided him when
without friends, or money to pay his debts or
subsist upon, and from motives of charity
gave him employ when not worth penny
Ask and reflect, does it argue well for Pat
rick to sting the hand OF his 6eacfact0r, tad
der like" that hand which nourished and
usttlned him?


Next, in order, would notice the knight
Of the Pous whose stupidity is only equalled
by his impudcnce in bringing into view the
name of my friend of the city of Lancaster,
whom he had induced to suppose that he
was man OF reputation and had decoyed
to his residence; which, when by me dis.
cerned, for the safety of his character and
person called for, considering him unsafe
in the company Of such "rehtlie."


now take leave of the Trustees OF St.
I Peters Church" patrick" and his guam
dam friend, the QuAck, intending on no fu-
ture occasion to notice their netarious pro-
ductlons,


VIM. LARKIN.
I Wilmington March z, ,1327.-25-4t.

Mr.. Billy Larkn Why are you barking at me, !,
We never had the change of AN unpleasant word.
1 know ofno cause Of your slanderously abusing
me, excepting my refusing you to put my shoul-
der, as you termed it, to shove your improper
paper, which you called your accompt current,
without day or date, truth, or even resemblance
OF truth. / showed it to Mr.. Wales, who is ono
OF the four law agents employed against you.-
DO you state there is no suit against YOU but
you will find that you must get better security
than yourself. You forget the night that the
Rev. MIR. Keenan, spent the evening with me in
December last, when you intrudcd yourself in
to my house, without an invitation. You then
heard Mr.. keenan, say he wished | would
come to Lancaster and live; and you also know
that Mr.. Keenan, is parish priest in Lancaster
and that he told you never lived in Lancaster
so see that telling lies is as necessary for your
support as meat and drink You forget when
you committed your falsehoods and defamations
to be published, that your attack on me must
be founded on envy and talsehood; as the public
know that advertise i'll this Borough in tive
newspapers to let every one in the Unitod
States know who am, what am, and where |
am, so that you are, to make the most of you,
| a bad minded man. The principle cause, be-
lievc, OF your behaviour, is my sending you back
pound OF spcrmaceti candles, which wanted a
quarter OF apound of the weight. done so to
prevent your doing 50 again-you, in an insolent
manner, told the woman that your weights were
as honest as mine. But this would not do, your
son mad to give hera pouIiI of candles, as she
| PAD you tor them, This is one ofthe causes of
your savage lying, and ,indictive malice.

WE, the trustees of st. Peters Church in the
Borough Of Wilmington, State of Delaware, see
ny an appeal to the public by William I.arkn,
wherein he charges us, Peter Pierce, Bernard
M'Cann, Hcrnard MGuigen, and John Durnin,
with uniustly assailing, and most wantonly SLAM
dciing, the said VIM. l.arkIn's character. lie
then proceeds 10 say he feels il duty lie owes
10 himself and his friends to repcl the unauthor-
iscl base and unfonuded charges made by those
calunn.atols, and expose them TO that contempt
u ey merit lie then comes forward, honest
inan like, 10 exhibit to public view u statement of
tho Ilcts connected with the lottery case alluded
10 he requests the public to recoIlect the pc
riod the Legislature granted the lottery, in 1922,
FOR raising the sum OF 5000 dollars for the use of
st Peters Church and payment of debts, over all
expenses; he then states the managers of the
iottcry then agreed that one of them should sign
the tickets, and receive the money, and pay
the prl2es--this was the most substantial part Of
the business, although poor Billy says it was un-
orunatc for him, or, as the seit-crcated trustees
would have il, it WAS unfortunate for the Church
! the trustees arc a set OF mpudent fellows, for
not pityng poor Billy's severe loss, and not the
losses ofthe church; poor Billy goes on to in
form the public he sold the lottery to Thomas
Hope, who commenced to sell the Tickets; and
after the sale OF the first and second classes, hon
est Billy tells tho public, with the most bare
faced fasehood, that he paid the church, in cash
and note, and payment ofdebts, the full amount
andupwar.s, SAY 1905 dollars. As he treats the
public opinion with the same insolcnce as he has
treated the congregation Of St. Peters Church,
We row challenge you to come before any three
or more respectable men Of the Borough, and we
are ready 10 meet any hour you appoint, face to
face, and if you can produce one solitary docu-
ncnt of receipt or settlement for any sum o
money, even for one dollar, since the commence
ment of the drawing Of the lottery until thi.
day, we shall acknowledge your assertion to be
true, and if YOU cannot produce any receipt ol
settlement from the trustees of ST. Peter.
Church YOU must be the most abandoned crea
turc upon earth--we challenge you to produce i
. in forty-eight hours, or you stand convicted, a.
you are; so that we shall prevent you from
. imposing any longer on the public. Our for
. bearance for so long time with you, was from
motives of charity, not wishing to niure you


character, as we would do, for any man in bust


ness; but we see you are the same obdurat
= and perverted wretch still, after all our indul


gence to you. We point out all infamous false


hood on the face Of the document you have SC


before the public, where you say you sold ST


classes of the lottery to Thomas Hope for so


dollars each, to be paid by Hope as each elias
was sold. You state that after the lst and I'd elias.
}. es were sold, you paid the church the sum
II 1905 dollars in cash and note. You could not pa


out Of one thousand dollars, which you state 70
VIM. LARKIN
Wilmington, March Z, 1327.-25'
TO TIIE PURL.IC

The population ofLynn is over 5000, near
ly all Of whom are supported by the shoe
business. From 1900 900 to /, 400, 900 pairs
OF shoes are made annually in the town, of
an average value OF rs cents per pair, max
ing nearly 100000 dollars. The females
OF the town make more than sixty thousand
dollars annually by binding and ornamenting
shoes. Millions Of low priced fancy shoes
have been sent to South America, and sold
al profit. There is chocolate manufac-
tory in LYNN, which makes sixty tons OF
chocolate in year. The Lynn fishermen
at this time bring in six thousand pounds OF
fish daiiy.-N. Hamh. Gag.

LUCERNE, OR FRENCH GLOVER.


Having been for eight or ten years in the
successful practice of the culture of Lucerne
think it may bcnehcially promote the in
terests of Agriculture, to offer YOU few
remarks on that subject. This article (fre-
ouently denominated French Clover) have
found, from experience, to be not only the
most convenient, but also the most profta-
BILE of all grasses. 1t vegetables quicker IN
the spring than any other grass; 1t resists
the effects of droughts; it may be cut four
or hye times in the course OF the season. and
will endure from ten to twelve years without
rene wing OF all other grasses, it is the
most profitable for soilng. ! am fully of O.
pion. that one acre properly got in, would
be more than sufficient to maintain at least
six head of cattle, from the first of May un-
til frost sets in; for before it can be cut
down in this way the first part will be again
ready for tile scythe. English writers have
recommended the drill system for this arti-
Gle, but in our climate, have found this is
entirely fallaciors. The proper mode is to
have your land properly prepared, to SOW
the seed broad cast, and to get it in during
she month of April, or in the early part of
HAY. Fall sowing will not answer, for like
clover. when sowed late, it is found not 70
resist the winters frost. 1t may be sowed
BY itself or with spring rye, barley, or oats;
but in the last case, / would recommend the
oats to be cut green, and before getting into
seed by which means, an early feed for cat
tie may be obtained, and the soil will not be
so much (if auy) impoverished. But the
mode l would most confidently recon-
mend, would be to SOW with the luccrne
about half bushel Of common or winter
rye. The effect of this is. that the rye
which vegetables quickly serves as nurse tt
the young grass, against the heat OF the
scorching sun; and by the time the gras
attains strength to support ITSELF the ry,
withers and apparently dies. 1t will, how
ever, come forth in the spring, and mixet
feed for cattle, and also add much to the
Quantity of fodder. The rye will admit o
being cut green this way, before getting
into seed, two or three times before II de.
Gays.


The quantity of seed would recommend
TO be sowed to the acre would be from Is t
90 ID. The kind of soil most suitable fol
this culture, is a dry mellow loan, but
sandy or clay loan will also answer, provid
ed they are not wet In favorable season
che lucerne may be kept the ensuing fall at
ter sowing. After the first season, you ma!
generally begin to cut green for cattle b,
the first of May, which saves your youn!
pastures, and is in every respect great con
venience, as hogs, and every description o
animals. deyour it with equal avidity.
produces great quantity of seed, and i
much more easily threshed out than clover
The second and third crops are the mos
productive of seed. Yours, &c.


J.PArRICK.


Perth Amboy, IN. j. July 10, 1925.

Mode IF securing Timber from decay


Timber for buildings, especially for ships,
bridges, canals, granaries, and stables may
be effectually preserved from decay, and
particularly the rot. by frequently mpreg-
mating the wood with d solution of common
salt and green copperas. This simple pro-
cessis attended with such decided advantage
that wood thus prepared will remain for
ages, perfectly souod. An instance of this
fact occurred in the theatre at Copenhagen,
where the lower part Of the planks and
joists formerly required to be replaced 10 a
few years, till Mr. Nolmelster, an architect
ofthat city, employed and employed the pro-
cess above stated. ~ years after the wood on
removing one Of the boards, was found III
such state of preservation that he could
not observe the least appearance of decay.


Eng. ia.

u - w = II
Perth Amboy, IN. j. July 10, 1925.

Job Printing,

rice Of the two classcsl so that one might think
,ou wronged Hope, or made sham sale OF the
ottery with an intent to defraud the church,
Al. Mr.. Billy, we have documents from Thomas
Homes hand, which firmly prove that the
nett profits on the first class after paying the
priyes, amounted to 1896 dollars; and that the
profits on the second class amounted to 47oo dol
lars. What an unfortunate business tor you'll
You say the third class was managed by Patrick
following will say to the contrary


Statement of Patrick Higgins.


81 shall state, as one Of the four managers OF
the Lottery, sold BY William; Larkin, principal
manager and treasurer, who received the pro-
cceds of the four classes of the Delaware l4otte-
ry, intended by the Legislature OF this State lor
the use and benefit of st. Peters Church IN tins
Borough, that after the first and second class
es were drawn, VIM I.arkin requested me to
take the management of the Sd class, as he SAID
he was fatigued told him | would do any
thing in nv power to assist the Church. lie
gave me the tickets, and some tune after ne
came TO me, with Arthur Murphy, and SAID ne
would not sign the tickets unless Murphy and
would give him bill of indemnity, that IN case
of loss in the third class, we should suffer like.
As poor Murphy and knew nothing more OF
Lottery schemes than an old woman, We signed
the bond now inform the public, that Will
liam Iarkin, sometime after this. pursuaded poor
Murphy to ioin with him and n. G. williamson,
and form a Board Of Managers, and take the
Lottery from me; which they did, and Larkin
and Tho's. Hope sold it between them. After
they took the third class from me, Larkin sent
his order to me to give Thomas Hope one thou
sand tickets, which order hold to this day
Alho' he states in the paper that it was under
my care the third class was sold l have Lar
kin's order and Hopes receipt for every ticket
he got from me. This is the rich harvest tho't
to save, which Larkin acknowledges to have dis
appointed me in. He states the sd class was all
under my care, which is false, as | have his own
order to prove il So This order and all the do
cuments relative to the Lottery, gave to Doc
tor Purcell by order of the Trustees; that, Lar
kin, every statement you made in the Whining
tonlan is false, and inform the public that [
know you these twenty five years, and that
have document relating TO you, to prove what
| say TO be true.


PAT'K HIGGINS.


Larkin calls US selfcreated tmstees-you
seem to forget the 18th of April 1924, when We
were the trustees, whom with the late and much
to be regretted Victor Du Pont, rejected your
rascally behaviour, and thrust you out of being
Treasurer ora Trustee ever since, in the Church
The last day we met you was in Doctor PercclPs
shop, where you began your old trade OF black
guarlng us. You know you promised that
day. which was the Esd Of January last, to bring
up your books, and appointed the Doctor to set
tie with the church on your part, and We ap
pointed the late and rcvered Victor Du Pont OF
our part; which you agreed to: after, we saw
Mr., Du Pont he said if you would carry up youI
books to Doctor Purcell to be examined, and il
the doctor could do any thing with the books re
spectng settlement, Mr. Du Pont would call OF
the Doctor on Saturday after,to consult with him
if they could arrange settlement. We return
ed to William Larkin and informed him of what
Mr.. Du Pont said to us-4.arkln's answer to u!
was, he had no books, and would settle no &C
counts. See this unprincipled man--equaly re
garlless Of his solemn promise, or of committing
sacrlcge. His actions arc the surcst standard
to Judge him by. After the Lottery was drawr
in January, 1924, we, the trustees of st. Peter.
Church, insisted on settlement from Larkin.-
What does this monster of inquity do TO ami
hilate the church and trustees, SO that, as he
supposed there would be none to demand the
proceeds ofthe Lottery of him-lIe causes vii
liam Boyd sue the Church for the amount Of hi'
bill, which was about $1,000, with an expectation
of Mr.. Boyd's getting Judgment and execution
and then selling the house. He did not wish Il
be bothered for Lottery money--he had q bette
use loi IL til'''i SNhS ~ " ~ S'S Va ot' 'u'
BY his Withholding from the Church the proceeds
Of the Lottery, he withholds from the widow anl
the orphan, and prevents numbers poor chill
dren of An early education, to make them usetu
members of society


| Larkin falsely charges DIR, Purcell with sowing
discord in the congrcgation-this we, the trus
tees Of st. Peters Church affirm to be false
hood We offered DR.. Purcell to take charge
of our funds, which he refused and We are Ger
tain nothing gives you more trouble than youl
not getting hold Of them, The balance of pew
rent and subscriptions to the church, which re
manned in your hands at the time you were re
moved from the office of Treasurer, you hold al
this time. You keep all our former books ant
church accounts, and thereby the church sus
tains great loss.


The pencil Of an Angelo or Raphael-the
tongue of Cicero, Rurk, Gratan, or Curran
would not be adequate to describe the peit'ly o.
that man. He is as dross among metal, chatf a.
Inong grain, a wolfamong sheep, and bad mem
Der among the children Of God.


| PETER PIERCE,
BERNARD M'GUIGEN,
/ BERNARD MCANN,
| JOHN DURNIN.
March /, 1897


i

full articles.headline: COOKING CABBAGE.
full articles.article:
We cannot here pass over the advice of
bruyerinus. respecting the preparing of cab
bage for the table.


81 must" says he. "expose an error
which is no less common than pernicious, in
preparing cabbage. Most people, in conse-
quence of the ignorance of their cooks, eat
it after it has been long boiled, a circum-
stance which does not little diminish both
its grateful taste and salutary qualities But
those who have more polite and elegant
turn. order their cabbage to be slightly boil
ed, put into dishes and seasoned with salt
and oil; by which method they assume a
beautiful green color, become grateful to
the taste, and proper for keeping the bo-
dy soluble. This circumstance ought not to
be forgotten by those who are lovers of cab
bage.


"The ancients Boiled their cabbage with
nitre, which rendered it at once more CRATE.
full to the palate and more agreeable to the
eye"


Phillips History Of Vegetables.

full articles.headline: ADVERTISEMENT. A
full articles.article:
To the Editor Of the ItiminStonian.


In your last Number, an additional toz2
and scurrious publication has appeared "a
gainst me from the famous would-oe rus
tees Of St. Peters Church, backed by the
certificate of Patrick Higgins, and the alter
picc, of the notorious Quack Doctor, OF Oh
hossum memory. That shameful production,
fraught with the most glaring falsehoods, is
degrading, and unworthy the character OF
apv Trustees, and which, as member, !
much regret.


/ have turned those "Trustees" over to
,he legal authority WHO have no doubt will
dulv appre ciate their wants, and do them
THAI in ,tict their infamous deeds deserve.
Nj statement, by way Of reply, in your
forncr paper, is substantially correct; and
have heen, and am ready and willingto settle
on lust aud equitable term, with the church,
with any men selected who are not devoid OF
/ principle, but ] ntver can condescend to
men s. destitute Of every principle that cha
ractcrizes the individuals who have so wan
tony ;ssaied my character


! With respect to the certificate OF Patrick,
| il is bundle of absurdities worthy the au-
thor He saws he has known me for TWEEN
| ty-fiye Years lit is true, and the only truth
he has asserted y: he has known me, and
have we'll known him to my sorrow. He can
advert to the time and we'll remember, who
! first started him in Thoroughfare Neck, and
who it was that was the loser thereby byhis ,r-
yegulQr spQys, and who afterwards helped
\ him back to Wilmington, and aided him when
without friends, or money to pay his debts or
subsist upon, and from motives of charity
gave him employ when not worth penny
Ask and reflect, does it argue well for Pat
rick to sting the hand OF his 6eacfact0r, tad
der like" that hand which nourished and
usttlned him?


Next, in order, would notice the knight
Of the Pous whose stupidity is only equalled
by his impudcnce in bringing into view the
name of my friend of the city of Lancaster,
whom he had induced to suppose that he
was man OF reputation and had decoyed
to his residence; which, when by me dis.
cerned, for the safety of his character and
person called for, considering him unsafe
in the company Of such "rehtlie."


now take leave of the Trustees OF St.
I Peters Church" patrick" and his guam
dam friend, the QuAck, intending on no fu-
ture occasion to notice their netarious pro-
ductlons,


VIM. LARKIN.
I Wilmington March z, ,1327.-25-4t.

full articles.headline: March l., 1897
full articles.article:
Mr.. Billy Larkn Why are you barking at me, !,
We never had the change of AN unpleasant word.
1 know ofno cause Of your slanderously abusing
me, excepting my refusing you to put my shoul-
der, as you termed it, to shove your improper
paper, which you called your accompt current,
without day or date, truth, or even resemblance
OF truth. / showed it to Mr.. Wales, who is ono
OF the four law agents employed against you.-
DO you state there is no suit against YOU but
you will find that you must get better security
than yourself. You forget the night that the
Rev. MIR. Keenan, spent the evening with me in
December last, when you intrudcd yourself in
to my house, without an invitation. You then
heard Mr.. keenan, say he wished | would
come to Lancaster and live; and you also know
that Mr.. Keenan, is parish priest in Lancaster
and that he told you never lived in Lancaster
so see that telling lies is as necessary for your
support as meat and drink You forget when
you committed your falsehoods and defamations
to be published, that your attack on me must
be founded on envy and talsehood; as the public
know that advertise i'll this Borough in tive
newspapers to let every one in the Unitod
States know who am, what am, and where |
am, so that you are, to make the most of you,
| a bad minded man. The principle cause, be-
lievc, OF your behaviour, is my sending you back
pound OF spcrmaceti candles, which wanted a
quarter OF apound of the weight. done so to
prevent your doing 50 again-you, in an insolent
manner, told the woman that your weights were
as honest as mine. But this would not do, your
son mad to give hera pouIiI of candles, as she
| PAD you tor them, This is one ofthe causes of
your savage lying, and ,indictive malice.


February %, 1897 oI-A.,

full articles.headline:
VIM. LARKIN

Wilmington, March Z, 1327.-25'

TO TIIE PURL.IC
full articles.article:
WE, the trustees of st. Peters Church in the
Borough Of Wilmington, State of Delaware, see
ny an appeal to the public by William I.arkn,
wherein he charges us, Peter Pierce, Bernard
M'Cann, Hcrnard MGuigen, and John Durnin,
with uniustly assailing, and most wantonly SLAM
dciing, the said VIM. l.arkIn's character. lie
then proceeds 10 say he feels il duty lie owes
10 himself and his friends to repcl the unauthor-
iscl base and unfonuded charges made by those
calunn.atols, and expose them TO that contempt
u ey merit lie then comes forward, honest
inan like, 10 exhibit to public view u statement of
tho Ilcts connected with the lottery case alluded
10 he requests the public to recoIlect the pc
riod the Legislature granted the lottery, in 1922,
FOR raising the sum OF 5000 dollars for the use of
st Peters Church and payment of debts, over all
expenses; he then states the managers of the
iottcry then agreed that one of them should sign
the tickets, and receive the money, and pay
the prl2es--this was the most substantial part Of
the business, although poor Billy says it was un-
orunatc for him, or, as the seit-crcated trustees
would have il, it WAS unfortunate for the Church
! the trustees arc a set OF mpudent fellows, for
not pityng poor Billy's severe loss, and not the
losses ofthe church; poor Billy goes on to in
form the public he sold the lottery to Thomas
Hope, who commenced to sell the Tickets; and
after the sale OF the first and second classes, hon
est Billy tells tho public, with the most bare
faced fasehood, that he paid the church, in cash
and note, and payment ofdebts, the full amount
andupwar.s, SAY 1905 dollars. As he treats the
public opinion with the same insolcnce as he has
treated the congregation Of St. Peters Church,
We row challenge you to come before any three
or more respectable men Of the Borough, and we
are ready 10 meet any hour you appoint, face to
face, and if you can produce one solitary docu-
ncnt of receipt or settlement for any sum o
money, even for one dollar, since the commence
ment of the drawing Of the lottery until thi.
day, we shall acknowledge your assertion to be
true, and if YOU cannot produce any receipt ol
settlement from the trustees of ST. Peter.
Church YOU must be the most abandoned crea
turc upon earth--we challenge you to produce i
. in forty-eight hours, or you stand convicted, a.
you are; so that we shall prevent you from
. imposing any longer on the public. Our for
. bearance for so long time with you, was from
motives of charity, not wishing to niure you


character, as we would do, for any man in bust


ness; but we see you are the same obdurat
= and perverted wretch still, after all our indul


gence to you. We point out all infamous false


hood on the face Of the document you have SC


before the public, where you say you sold ST


classes of the lottery to Thomas Hope for so


dollars each, to be paid by Hope as each elias
was sold. You state that after the lst and I'd elias.
}. es were sold, you paid the church the sum
II 1905 dollars in cash and note. You could not pa


out Of one thousand dollars, which you state 70

full articles.headline: SHOES IN LYNN.
full articles.article:
The population ofLynn is over 5000, near
ly all Of whom are supported by the shoe
business. From 1900 900 to /, 400, 900 pairs
OF shoes are made annually in the town, of
an average value OF rs cents per pair, max
ing nearly 100000 dollars. The females
OF the town make more than sixty thousand
dollars annually by binding and ornamenting
shoes. Millions Of low priced fancy shoes
have been sent to South America, and sold
al profit. There is chocolate manufac-
tory in LYNN, which makes sixty tons OF
chocolate in year. The Lynn fishermen
at this time bring in six thousand pounds OF
fish daiiy.-N. Hamh. Gag.

full articles.headline:
THE FARMER.

From the New.England Farmer.
LUCERNE, OR FRENCH CLOVER
full articles.article:
LUCERNE, OR FRENCH GLOVER.


Having been for eight or ten years in the
successful practice of the culture of Lucerne
think it may bcnehcially promote the in
terests of Agriculture, to offer YOU few
remarks on that subject. This article (fre-
ouently denominated French Clover) have
found, from experience, to be not only the
most convenient, but also the most profta-
BILE of all grasses. 1t vegetables quicker IN
the spring than any other grass; 1t resists
the effects of droughts; it may be cut four
or hye times in the course OF the season. and
will endure from ten to twelve years without
rene wing OF all other grasses, it is the
most profitable for soilng. ! am fully of O.
pion. that one acre properly got in, would
be more than sufficient to maintain at least
six head of cattle, from the first of May un-
til frost sets in; for before it can be cut
down in this way the first part will be again
ready for tile scythe. English writers have
recommended the drill system for this arti-
Gle, but in our climate, have found this is
entirely fallaciors. The proper mode is to
have your land properly prepared, to SOW
the seed broad cast, and to get it in during
she month of April, or in the early part of
HAY. Fall sowing will not answer, for like
clover. when sowed late, it is found not 70
resist the winters frost. 1t may be sowed
BY itself or with spring rye, barley, or oats;
but in the last case, / would recommend the
oats to be cut green, and before getting into
seed by which means, an early feed for cat
tie may be obtained, and the soil will not be
so much (if auy) impoverished. But the
mode l would most confidently recon-
mend, would be to SOW with the luccrne
about half bushel Of common or winter
rye. The effect of this is. that the rye
which vegetables quickly serves as nurse tt
the young grass, against the heat OF the
scorching sun; and by the time the gras
attains strength to support ITSELF the ry,
withers and apparently dies. 1t will, how
ever, come forth in the spring, and mixet
feed for cattle, and also add much to the
Quantity of fodder. The rye will admit o
being cut green this way, before getting
into seed, two or three times before II de.
Gays.


The quantity of seed would recommend
TO be sowed to the acre would be from Is t
90 ID. The kind of soil most suitable fol
this culture, is a dry mellow loan, but
sandy or clay loan will also answer, provid
ed they are not wet In favorable season
che lucerne may be kept the ensuing fall at
ter sowing. After the first season, you ma!
generally begin to cut green for cattle b,
the first of May, which saves your youn!
pastures, and is in every respect great con
venience, as hogs, and every description o
animals. deyour it with equal avidity.
produces great quantity of seed, and i
much more easily threshed out than clover
The second and third crops are the mos
productive of seed. Yours, &c.


J.PArRICK.


Perth Amboy, IN. j. July 10, 1925.

full articles.headline:
u - w = II
Perth Amboy, IN. j. July 10, 1925.

Mode IF securing Timber from decay
full articles.article:
Mode IF securing Timber from decay


Timber for buildings, especially for ships,
bridges, canals, granaries, and stables may
be effectually preserved from decay, and
particularly the rot. by frequently mpreg-
mating the wood with d solution of common
salt and green copperas. This simple pro-
cessis attended with such decided advantage
that wood thus prepared will remain for
ages, perfectly souod. An instance of this
fact occurred in the theatre at Copenhagen,
where the lower part Of the planks and
joists formerly required to be replaced 10 a
few years, till Mr. Nolmelster, an architect
ofthat city, employed and employed the pro-
cess above stated. ~ years after the wood on
removing one Of the boards, was found III
such state of preservation that he could
not observe the least appearance of decay.


Eng. ia.

Of with il IN infinite pumbcr Of partici
which it will afterwards deposit in the forui
of white powder. separable by decantatio",
which powder is starch, possessing all the
essential properties of wheaton starch.
